questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with a painless testicular mass. Inguinal orchidectomy was done and the gross and histological image is given below.  What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The gross specimen showing a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface that bulges around the surrounding parenchyma is characteristic of a seminomatous germ-cell tumor or seminoma.

The histological image shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus (fried-egg appearance), delicate fibrous septa containing a lymphocytic infiltrate.

Seminoma is the most common type of GCT. The peak incidence is the 3rd decade and almost never occurs in infants. It is the testicular equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, (regardless of KIT mutational status), OCT3/4, and placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP).

Option B: Yolk sac tumor is non-encapsulated with mucinous appearance. Schiller–Duval bodies are characteristic. It is seen in children less than 3 years.

Option C: Teratoma shows derivatives of more than one germ layer like cartilage, hair, sebaceous glands.

Option D: Testicular lymphoma is a rare extranodal presentation of non-Hodgkin lymphoma

Testicular biopsy is contraindicated in case of a suspicious testicular mass because it is associated with a risk of tumor cell spillage. High inguinal orchidectomy followed by histopathological evaluation is the preferred standard management. Fixative used for testicular biopsy is Bouin's fluid.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with hemoptysis and loss of weight. Chest radiograph shows multiple canon-ball metastases. Physical examination revealed no palpable mass. The serum HCG level is raised, but no change in AFP and CEA  levels. Biopsy from the lung lesion reveals the following finding. What is the most likely primary tumor?

From the given clinical scenario and image showing cytotrophoblasts and multinucleated syncytiotrophoblasts in a hemorrhagic background, the most likely primary tumor appears to be choriocarcinoma.

The syncytiotrophoblasts secrete β-hCG, at levels that serve as important serological markers.

Pure choriocarcinoma, although rare, is the most aggressive non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT). It often does not cause any testicular enlargement; instead, it spreads rapidly via the bloodstream. This results in the frequent involvement of the lung(cannon-ball metastases) and liver and a poor prognosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with dyspnea and cough. Chest X-ray revealed irregular linear densities, particularly in both lower lobes. Histopathological examination of lung biopsy is shown below. This patient has a higher risk of developing:
questions.solution:
The image shows golden-brown, beaded rods with a translucent center called asbestos bodies which are seen in asbestosis. These patients are at risk of developing both lung carcinoma and mesothelioma.

Asbestosis is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis and the presence of multiple asbestos bodies.

Option A: Centrilobular emphysema may develop in simple coal workers' pneumoconiosis. 

Option B: Increased susceptibility to tuberculosis is seen in silicosis. 

Option C: Occupational asthma may be triggered by fumes (epoxy resins, plastics), organic and chemical dust (wood, cotton, platinum), gases (toluene), or other chemicals (formaldehyde, penicillin products).

questions.text: A 50-year-old man admitted to ICU develops sepsis 3 days after insertion of a central venous catheter. A peripheral blood smear reveals the following. What does the structure marked by the arrow indicate?
questions.solution:
The given peripheral smear, prepared from an individual with bacterial sepsis, shows reactive changes in neutrophils. The arrow-marked structure is a Döhle body.

Reactive changes in neutrophils associated with leukocytosis in severe inflammatory disorders are:

  • Toxic granules, which are coarser and darker than the normal neutrophilic granules, represent abnormal azurophilic (primary) granules
  • Döhle bodies are patches of the dilated endoplasmic reticulum that appear as sky-blue cytoplasmic puddles
  • Toxic cytoplasmic vacuoles 

The image given below shows a neutrophil with cytoplasmic vacuoles.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with pain over the lower end of his left femur for the past 6 months,histological picture is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows a chicken wire calcification typically seen in chondroblastoma.
  • The common presenting age of chondroblastoma is 10–25 years of age and with 2: 1 male predominance.
  • The most common site is the distal femur, proximal humerus, and proximal tibia.
  • Microscopically chondroblastoma consists of a sheet of chondroblasts embedded in the chondroid matrix.
  • The calcification is often present and surrounds individual cell giving the appearance of ‘Chicken wire.’

Note-Chicken wire pattern of vascularity is seen in oligodendroglioma.

questions.text: A patient is to be started on dialectical behaviour therapy. Which of the following personality disorders is this used to manage?
questions.solution:
Dialectical behavior therapy (DBT), a form of psychotherapy is used in the management of borderline personality disorder.

It is the treatment of choice for borderline personality disorder and is effective, especially for those with parasuicidal behavior, such as frequent cutting.

Patients are seen weekly, to improve interpersonal skills and decrease self-destructive behavior using techniques involving advice, metaphor, storytelling, and confrontation.

DBT is influenced by the philosophical perspective of dialectics: "balancing opposites". It helps the individual to find ways to hold two seemingly opposite perspectives at once, promoting balance and avoiding the all-or-nothing style of thinking.

Other modalities of treatment include:

  • Mentalization-based treatment.
  • Transference-focused psychotherapy.
  • Drugs – antipsychotics, antidepressants (SSRI, TCA), and mood-stabilizing drugs.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient has complaints of painless cervical lymphadenopathy with fever, malaise, and weight loss. A lymph node was biopsied and the findings are as shown below.  All are true about the condition except

Hodgkin lymphoma is a group of lymphoid neoplasms arising in a single node and spreads from the nodes to spleen, then the liver, and finally bone marrow.

questions.text: The structure in the myeloblast seen in the slide given below is made of __________
questions.solution:
The slide shows Auer rods in myeloblasts. Auer rods are needle-shaped azurophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies formed by the fusion of lysosomes.

Auer rods contain peroxidase and lysosomal enzymes. 

Auer rods are seen in:

  • acute leukemia (myeloblastic, promyelocytic, monomyelocytic and monocytic)
  • myelodysplastic syndromes (RAEB-2) 
  • chronic myelomonocytic leukemia

Myeloblasts with bundles of Auer rods are known as faggot cells which are seen in acute promyelocytic leukemia.

questions.text: An anxious mother brought her 4-year-old daughter to the pediatrician. The girl was passing loose, bulky stools for the past 4 days. This was often associated with pain in the abdomen. The pediatrician ordered stool examination, which showed the following organisms. Which vitamin deficiency is the child at the greatest risk for?
questions.solution:
The stool examination (image) shows pear-shaped trophozoites having two nuclei and a flagellum, typical of Giardia lamblia. Giardiasis is associated with a deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins like vitamin A.

Giardia lamblia is transmitted via contaminated drinking water.

Clinical features include acute infectious diarrhea or chronic diarrhea, failure to thrive, and abdominal pain. Stools initially may be profuse and watery and later become greasy and foul-smelling. Stools do not contain blood, mucus, or leukocytes. It is associated with fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies, iron deficiency, and growth stunting.

Diagnosis is done by stool enzyme immunoassay (EIA) or direct fluorescent antibody tests for Giardia antigens; EIA is superior to microscopy.

Treatment includes tinidazole and nitazoxanide.

questions.text: An 11-year-old child, born out of consanguineous marriage developed signs and symptoms of hemolytic anemia and progressive ataxia. He is a known case of retinitis pigmentosa and also had symptoms of fat malabsorption. A peripheral smear of the child is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features along with the peripheral smear showing acanthocytes make the diagnosis of abetalipoproteinemia more likely.

Abetalipoproteinemia is an autosomal recessive hemolytic disorder in which acanthocytosis is associated with fat malabsorption, progressive ataxia, and retinitis pigmentosa.

Acanthocytes or spur cells are spiculated red cells with a few projections of varying size and surface distribution. The most significant associations include abetalipoproteinemia and severe liver disease.

Note: Do not confuse acanthocytes with echinocytes or burr cells. They appear with multiple small projections that are uniformly distributed on the red cell surface. It is a universal feature of uremia.

Image: The peripheral smear below shows regularly spaced, smoothly rounded crenulations, which are characteristic of a burr cell.

Hemolytic uremic syndrome (option A); Numerous schistocytes and nucleated RBCs with extremely low platelets:

 

Glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (option B); bite cells or degmacytes or blister cells. In G6PD deficiency uncontrolled oxidative stress causes hemoglobin to denature and form Heinz bodies. Bite cells result from the removal of Heinz bodies by macrophages in the spleen.

The image below shows bite cells represented by blue arrows, black arrows represent burr cells:

questions.text: An older patient with bilateral hearing loss and occasional vertigo is being investigated. Biopsy from the region is given below. The most likely diagnosis is _____.
questions.solution:
The given histology image shows dense pink Antoni A areas predominantly (bottom left) and loose, pale Antoni B areas (top right), as well as hyalinized blood vessels seen in schwannoma.

Schwannomas are benign tumors that exhibit Schwann cell differentiation and often arise directly from peripheral nerves. They are associated with inactivating mutations in the NF2 (Neurofibromatosis 2) gene on chromosome 22.

They appear as well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that are attached loosely to the associated nerve without invading. They cause symptoms by local compression of the involved nerve or adjacent structures.

Their cell of origin is the Schwann cell, thus they show immunoreactivity for the S-100 marker.

Treatment is done using surgical removal.

Other options:

Option A: Leiomyomas are benign smooth muscle tumors, that often arise in the uterus and are the most common neoplasm in women. Histologically, they are composed of fascicles of densely eosinophilic spindle cells that tend to intersect each other at right angles. 

Option B: Rhabdomyomas are the most frequent primary tumors of the heart in children. Microscopically, they are composed of bizarre, markedly enlarged myocytes with abundant glycogen. But due to routine histological processing, the glycogen content is reduced and looks like thin strands that stretch from the nuclei to the surface membrane, which appears like ‘spider cells’.

Option D: Neurofibromas are also benign nerve sheath tumors and the histological picture shows the presence of bland Schwann cells admixed with stromal cells such as mast cells, perineural cells, and fibroblasts. The stroma of the tumors contains loose collagen arranged in wavy bundles.

questions.text: A patient presents with generalized exfoliative erythroderma. The peripheral blood smear shows the following cell. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a classical Sezary cell with cerebriform nuclei which points towards a diagnosis of Sezary syndrome. These are neoplastic T cells.

Sezary syndrome and mycosis fungoides are different manifestations of tumors of CD4+ helper T cells that are home to the skin.

Sezary syndrome is a variant presenting as generalized exfoliative erythroderma. It rarely goes into tumefaction and there is associated leukemia of Sezary cells.

In Mycosis fungoides, only the epidermis and upper dermis are infiltrated by neoplastic T cells with the characteristic cerebriform appearance. In the later stages of the disease, progression occurs to lymph nodes and bone marrow. Tumour cells are not seen in blood. The disease progresses through the premycotic phase, plaque phase, and tumour phase.

questions.text: A farmer from the sub-Himalayan belt had a thorn prick injury a year back and developed a warty, verrucous growth at the site of prick. A skin biopsy sample was taken and sent for histopathological examination. The characteristic microscopic body as shown in the image was seen. questions.solution:
The history of a slowly spreading warty, verrucous lesion following a thorn prick injury and the histopathological image showing medlar bodies is suggestive of chromoblastomycosis.

Chromoblastomycosis (chromomycosis) is a subcutaneous mycotic infection that is usually caused by traumatic inoculation. Over months to years, the primary lesion becomes verrucous and wart-like with extension along the draining lymphatics.

questions.solution:
A-Normal liver

B-Alcoholic steatosis:

questions.text: Histopathological examination of a lymph node is as seen below. Which of the following condition does this pathology represent?
questions.solution:
Microscopy shows a granuloma formed by epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleate giant cells and surrounded by lymphocytes. This is an example for Type IV or cell mediated hypersensitivity reaction.

Type IV or cell mediated hypersensitivity reaction:

  • Seen with persistent or nondegradable antigens, such as tubercle bacilli in lungs or other tissues. Infiltrate is dominated by macrophages over a period of 2 or 3 weeks.
  • With sustained activation, macrophages often undergo a morphologic transformation into epithelioid cells (large epithelium-like cells with abundant cytoplasm).
  • A microscopic aggregation of epithelioid cells, usually surrounded by a collar of lymphocytes, is referred to as a granuloma.
  • This pattern of inflammation, called granulomatous inflammation is typically associated with strong TH1-cell activation and high-level production of cytokines such as IFN-γ.

questions.text: An incidental, rounded radio-opacity (coin lesion) is discovered on a routine chest film. The lesion is resected and microscopy is as seen below. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Microscopy shows epithelial clefts lined by ciliated columnar epithelium or nonciliated epithelium with mature adipose tissue and benign cartilage.

The most likely diagnosis is pulmonary hamartoma.

  • Most common benign tumor of the lung, most often with a chondromatous element.
  • A relatively common lesion that is usually discovered as an incidental, rounded radio-opacity (coin lesion) on a routine chest film.
  • Typically solitary, <4 cm, composed of disordered but mature hyaline cartilage, fibrous tissue, smooth muscle, fat, sometimes with calcification/ossification.
  • Cartilage is the most common connective tissue.
  • The epithelial clefts are lined by ciliated columnar epithelium or nonciliated epithelium and probably represent entrapment of respiratory epithelium.
  • Nonfamilial Carney triad: Pulmonary chondroma, gastric stromal tumors, functional extra-adrenal paraganglioma.

questions.text: The images below display the gross and microscopic features of a brain tumour in a child. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gross features (cystic tumor) and microscopy (microcystic and fibrillary areas) suggest pilocytic astrocytoma.

Pilocytic astrocytomas typically occur in children and young adults. It is located in the cerebellum, floor, and walls of the third ventricle, the optic nerves, and cerebral hemispheres. It is often cystic. Tumors are often biphasic, with both loose microcystic and fibrillary areas. Bipolar cells with long, thin “hairlike” processes that are GFAP-positive and form dense fibrillary meshwork are seen.

Rosenthal fibers and eosinophilic granular bodies are characteristic findings. Necrosis and brisk mitotic activity are uncommon.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man from the eastern part of India presents with a shallow and slowly expanding ulcer with heaped-up borders over the face. Biopsy reveals granulomas and the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows many histiocytes containing Leishman–Donovan bodies and surrounding chronic inflammatory cells classically seen in cutaneous leishmaniasis.

Cutaneous leishmaniasis presents with a shallow and slowly expanding ulcer, often with heaped-up borders.

On microscopic examination, the lesion shows granulomatous inflammation, usually with many giant cells and few parasites.

Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis is characterized by a single skin nodule, which continues spreading until the entire body is covered by nodular lesions. Microscopically, they contain aggregates of foamy macrophages stuffed with leishmania.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is correctly matched with its layer of origin?
questions.solution:
The area marked ‘2’ depicts the zona fasciculata, which secretes glucocorticoids. In ACTH-independent Cushing’s syndrome, excess cortisol is produced from this layer. 

Parts of the adrenal glands:

  • The adrenal cortex is arranged in a zonal configuration in three zones - 
    • Outer zona glomerulosa- secretes mineralocorticoids (aldosterone)
    • Middle zona fasciculata- secretes glucocorticoids (cortisol, corticosterone)
    • Inner zona reticularis- secretes androgens (dehydroepiandrosterone)
  • The adrenal medulla- stores and secretes catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine)

On histological examination, the different layers are identified as:

  • Outer zona glomerulosa - small, compact cells
  • Central zona fasciculata - larger lipid-rich cells arranged in radial columns
  • Inner zona reticularis - pigmented, compact cells
  • Adrenal medulla - thin layer of large chromaffin cells

Option A: Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine producing tumour derived from chromaffin cells and arises from the adrenal medulla.

Option C: In Conn’s syndrome, excess aldosterone is secreted from zona glomerulosa.

Option D: Neuroblastoma arises from the adrenal medulla.

The cells of the glomerulosa are arranged in round-to-oval clusters that resemble renal glomeruli, and hence, this layer is called "glomerulosa".

questions.text: A pathologist is examining the following renal biopsy specimen. What does it show?

choices.text: Proliferating  parietal and visceral epithelial  cells and WBCs in Bowman space
Diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall
Proliferating mesangial cells and increased matrix deposition in the mesangium
Proliferation of capillaries with fibrin deposition

questions.solution:
The given image shows a crescent-shaped mass of proliferating parietal and visceral epithelial cells and leukocytes within the Bowman capsule. It is a characteristic feature of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) or crescentic glomerulonephritis.

RPGN is a type of nephritic syndrome associated with severe glomerular injury with necrosis and formation of crescents. It is usually immune-mediated and may be associated with circulating anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs), anti-GBM antibodies, and antinuclear antibodies (ANA).

Injury to the glomerular capillary wall leads to the escape of procoagulant factors and cytokines in the Bowman space. This triggers:

  • Proliferation of glomerular epithelial cells - mostly parietal, but also some visceral cells 
  • Recruitment of leukocytes and fibroblasts 
  • Pathognomonic crescents - due to the circumferential accumulation of these cells and fibrin

The crescents progressively compress the capillary tuft. This results in a rapid decline of glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and, consequently, acute kidney injury (AKI). Thus, the degree of crescent formation correlates with the severity and the prognosis of the disease.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with a worsening headache for 8 months. A left sub frontal mass is resected. Microscopy is as seen below and tumor cells express progesterone receptors.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Microscopy shows a tumor with meningothelial whorls, syncytial cells with indistinct cell membranes and psammoma bodies. Most likely diagnosis is a meningioma.

Meningioma: They are predominantly benign tumors of adults, usually attached to the dura, that arise from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid.

  • Meningiomas may be found along any of the external surfaces of the brain as well as within the ventricular system, where they arise from the stromal arachnoid cells of the choroid plexus.
  • Prior radiation therapy to the head and neck, typically is a risk factor.
  • The most common cytogenetic abnormality is loss of chromosome 22, especially the long arm (22q).
  • Meningiomas are a common lesion in the setting of NF2 (multiple sites, especially in association with acoustic neuromas or glial tumors.
  • The surface of the mass is usually encapsulated.
  • They may also grow en plaque, in which the tumor spreads in a sheetlike fashion along the surface of the dura. This form is commonly associated with hyperostotic reactive changes in the adjacent bone.
  • The lesions may contain numerous calcified psammoma bodies.

Histological subtypes:

  • WHO Grade I – Menigothelial, fibroblastic, transitional, psammomatous, secretory, microcystic
  • WHO Grade II- Clear cell, chordoid, atypical
  • Grade III – Papillary, rhabdoid, anaplastic
  • Atypical meningiomas (WHO grade II/IV) - a higher rate of recurrence and more aggressive local growth
  • Anaplastic (malignant) meningioma (WHO grade III/IV) - highly aggressive tumor with the appearance of a high-grade sarcoma
  • Immunoreactive for epithelial membrane antigen
  • Keratin is restricted to lesions with the secretory pattern, and these tumors are also positive for carcinoembryonic antigen
  • Moderate (3: 2) female predominance, usually solitary, but when present at multiple sites, the possibility of neurofibromatosis type 2 should be considered.
  • Meningiomas often express progesterone receptors and may grow more rapidly during pregnancy.

questions.text: A young lady complains of recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge and bilateral nasal blockage for two years.  She has a history of allergic rhinitis. On rhinoscopy, multiple ethmoidal polyps with mucosal thickening and impacted secretions are seen in both the nasal cavities. A tissue biopsy is taken and sent for culture, which on microscopic examination shows the following appearance. What is the most probable organism implicated here?
questions.solution:
Recurrent rhinitis, chronic nasal discharge, bilateral nasal blockage, multiple ethmoidal polyps and the microscopic appearance of conical vesicles with conidia over two-thirds of the vesicle is suggestive of allergic fungal rhinosinusitis caused by Aspergillus fumigatus.

Aspergillus spp. can lead to the following types of sinusitis:

  1. Acute invasive sinusitis: It affects immunocompromised patients. They present with fever, nasal or facial discomfort, blocked nose and bloody nasal discharge. Pale, dusky or necrotic tissue will be present within the sinuses.
  2. Chronic aspergillus sinusitis:
    • Fungal ball of sinus: The maxillary sinus, most commonly, is filled with an aspergillus ball. No tissue invasion is present.
    • Chronic invasive sinusitis: There is slow destruction of the ethmoid and sphenoid sinuses with bone destruction and localised spread. Patients present with chronic nasal discharge and blockage, loss of the sense of smell and persistent headache. Involvement of the orbit results in proptosis and blindness.
    • Chronic granulomatous sinusitis: Patients present with facial swelling and unilateral proptosis. Biopsied tissue shows granulomatous (not necrotic) reaction.
  3. Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis: Patients present with chronic sinusitis and nasal polyps. On microscopy, eosinophilia and Charcot-Leyden crystals can be seen.

On microscopic examination of the sinus or polyp tissue, hyaline, septate, acute branching hyphae of Aspergillus spp. can be seen. The various species can be differentiated based on the appearance of the conidiophores. In Aspergillus fumigatus, the vesicle is conical. Phialides are arranged in a single row. Conidia arise from the upper two-thirds of the vesicle and are hyaline.

Option B: Aspergillus flavus has a globular vesicle. Phialides are arranged in one or two rows. Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are hyaline.

Option C: Aspergillus niger has a globular-shaped vesicle. Phialides are in two rows. Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are black.

Option D: Penicillium chrysogenum has septate hyphae with branched conidiophores bearing chains of spores (brush or broom appearance).

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is being evaluated for hematuria after UTI. Histopathology showed mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation. The following finding is seen on immunofluorescence, which was positive for C3 and negative for IgG. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, histopathology findings of mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation, as well as immunofluorescence showing mesangial deposits are suggestive of IgA nephropathy (Berger's disease).

It is the most common type of glomerulonephritis worldwide. It is characterized by recurrent hematuria/ nephritic syndrome and the presence of prominent IgA deposits in the mesangium. Patients generally present with gross hematuria after respiratory, gastrointestinal or urinary tract infection.

The systemic variant of IgA nephropathy is called Henoch–Schönlein purpura. It is a disorder of children which presents with similar renal manifestations with characteristic IgA deposits in the mesangium in about one-third of the patients.

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient who presented with generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given peripheral smear shows tumor cells with multilobulated nuclei called cloverleaf or flower cells. This is characteristic of adult T-Cell leukemia/lymphoma.

This condition occurs in adults infected by human T-cell leukemia retrovirus type 1 (HTLV-1). It is a rapidly progressive disease that is fatal within months to one year following diagnosis. It is characterized by the following clinical features:

  • Skin lesions
  • Generalized lymphadenopathy
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Peripheral blood lymphocytosis,
  • Hypercalcemia

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes with complaints of fever and increasing fatigue for the past week. On examination, he is febrile, hypotensive and tachycardic. The findings of microscopic examination of his peripheral blood smear is given below. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Fever, fatigue, hypotension, tachycardia and the blood smear showing multiple ring forms in RBCs are suggestive of malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum.

Falciparum malaria, or malignant tertian malaria, is the most serious malaria. Plasmodium falciparum infects both young and mature erythrocytes, resulting in a large population of erythrocytes affected. Affected erythrocytes display cytoadherence, form rosettes and cause capillary plugging in vital organs like the brain, kidney, lungs etc. Diagnosis is by demonstration of P. falciparum in peripheral blood smear. The peripheral smear findings of falciparum malaria include:

  • Multiple ring forms: Multiple delicate rings are visible within the erythrocytes
  • Double chromatin: Binucleate ring forms resembling stereo headphones
  • Accole form or form applique: Ring forms are attached to the margins of red cells
  • Maurer's dots or clefts: Coarse brick red dots within erythrocytes
  • Banana shaped gametocytes within erythrocytes
  • Absent schizont

questions.text: A 35 year old male presented with a chronic non-healing ulcer over the leg. He gives history of  gall stones, severe pain the digits of hands and feet as well as an episode of salmonella osteomyelitis. He was immunised earlier because the physician told him that he has greater chance of infection caused by capsulated organisms. His peripheral smear is shown in the figure. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows sickle cells, target cells and polychromasia suggestive of sickle cell anaemia.

  • Sickle cell disease is caused by a point mutation in the sixth codon of β-globin that leads to the replacement of a glutamate residue with a valine residue.
  • HbS molecules stack into polymers when deoxygenated. With continued deoxygenation HbS molecules assemble into long needle-like fibers within red cells, producing a distorted sickle or holly-leaf shape.
  • Polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin, leading to red cell distortion, hemolytic anemia, microvascular obstruction, and ischemic tissue damage.
  • The major pathologic manifestations— Chronic hemolysis, microvascular occlusions, and tissue damage.
  • Peripheral blood demonstrates -  Irreversibly sickled cells, reticulocytosis, and target cells, which result from red cell dehydration with Howell-Jolly bodies.
  • Hyperplastic bone marrow-àExpansion of the marrow -àbone resorption and secondary new bone formation, -  “crewcut” on x-ray studies.
  • Increased breakdown of hemoglobin -  pigment gallstones and hyperbilirubinemia
  • Early childhood- Splenomegaly,  Adolesence- fibrosis, and progressive shrinkage, - autosplenectomy
  • Priapism affects up to 45% of males. Leg ulcers may be present.
  • Stroke and retinopathy leading to loss of visual acuity and even blindness
  • Vaso-occlusive crises,or pain crises -  episodes of hypoxic injury and infarction that cause severe pain in the affected region - hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis
  • Acute chest syndrome- vaso-occlusive crisis involving the lungs with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates.
  • Sequestration crises – In children with intact spleens. Massive entrapment of sickle red cells leads to rapid splenic enlargement, hypovolemia, and sometimes shock.
  • Aplastic crises - infection of red cell progenitors by parvovirus B19, which causes a transient cessation of erythropoiesis and a sudden worsening of the anemia
  • Increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms is another threat. due to altered splenic function
  • Pneumococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae septicemia and meningitis are common, particularly in children, but can be reduced by vaccination and prophylactic antibiotics.
  • Diagnosis - Mixing a blood sample with metabisulfite, which induces sickling of red cells if HbS is present.
  • Hemoglobin electrophoresis is also used to demonstrate the presence of HbS.

questions.text: The lymph node biopsy of a patient with lymphoma is given below. It shows two different cell populations labeled as A and B. Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Cells labelled A will test positive for CD14, CD40, CD11b & CD64
The fraction of cells with positive Ki67 staining is 100%
Cells labelled B will test positive for CD19, CD10, BCL-6 & CD43
Cells labelled B represent the stars in starry sky appearance

questions.solution:
The given image shows the characteristic starry sky appearance of Burkitt's lymphoma. The reactive macrophages (labelled as A) represent the stars in starry sky appearance. On the other hand, the homogenous tumour cells (labelled as B) represent the sky.

The neoplastic cells are homogeneous, medium-sized B cells with a high growth fraction. These cells are positive for CD19, CD10, BCL-6 & CD43.

Reactive macrophages are scattered throughout the tumour. Their pale cytoplasm in a background of blue-staining tumour cells gives the tumor a so-called starry sky appearance. Reactive leukocytes and macrophages are not stained by special stains. They are positive for CD14, CD40, CD11b & CD64.

The growth fraction of these lymphomas is very high, with frequent mitotic figures. The fraction of Ki-67+ (MIB-1+) stained cells is nearly 100%.

questions.text: A peripheral smear of a 40-year-old female with chronic anaemia and gall stones is as seen below. The patient develops a sudden worsening of anaemia requiring transfusion. What is the most likely Etiology?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows many spherocytes classically described in hereditary spherocytosis.

  • The generally stable clinical course of hereditary spherocytosis is sometimes punctuated by an aplastic crisis, usually triggered by an acute parvovirus infection.
  • Parvovirus infects and kills red cell progenitors, effectively causing red cell production to cease until an immune response commences, generally in 1 to 2 weeks.
  • The reduced life span of HS red cells + cessation of erythropoiesis → leads to a sudden worsening of the anemia.
  • Transfusions may be necessary to support the patient until the immune response clears the infection

questions.text: A young sexually active man presented with multiple polypoid growths over his penis. Histopathological image of an excised lesion is as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image showing papillary (villous) architecture with acanthosis, hyperkeratosis and koilocytosis of squamous epithelium, are characteristic findings of condyloma acuminatum.

Koilocytes have a prominent cell membrane, hyperchromatic resinoid nucleus, and perinuclear halo.

Grossly, they consist of single or multiple sessile or pedunculated, red papillary excrescences on the coronal sulcus, and the inner surface of the prepuce.

Option A: Condyloma lata is a maculopapular/nodular lesion seen in secondary syphilis.

Option B: Bowen's disease is carcinoma in situ of the penis characterized by the hyperproliferative epidermis and dysplastic epithelium.

Option D: Verrucous carcinoma / very well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, shows hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and keratin pearls.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient presented with abdominal pain and melena. On endoscopy, a bleeding gastric mass with irregular borders was identified along the greater curvature of the stomach. Microscopy is as shown in the image below. Which of the following is a specific marker for the tumor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histological picture showing spindle-shaped tumor cells are suggestive of gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST), for which CD 117 is the specific marker. 

GIST is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen, with the most common site being the stomach. The tumor arises from the interstitial cells of Cajal or pacemaker cells of the gastrointestinal muscularis propria.

Most GISTs occur due to gain-of-function mutations in receptor tyrosine kinase KIT (~75%) or PDGRF-ɑ (~8%). 

The tumor peaks at 60 years of age. It is often associated with the Carney triad, a nonhereditary condition characterized by GIST, paraganglioma, and pulmonary chondroma. GIST also has a higher incidence in individuals with neurofibromatosis I.

Patients typically present with anemia (due to blood loss caused by mucosal ulceration) and symptoms of mass effect. However, GISTs may also be discovered incidentally during imaging or surgery.

Microscopically, GIST can be of two patterns:

  1. Spindle cell type: The tumor is composed of thin elongated cells.
  2. Epitheloid type: The tumor is composed of plump epithelial-like cells.

Mixed patterns may also be seen.

The most useful immunohistochemical marker is KIT (CD117) detectable in Cajal cells, along with DOG1.

The prognosis depends on tumor size, mitotic index, and location (GISTs arising in the stomach are less aggressive than those arising in the small intestine). Complete surgical resection is the mainstay treatment. For unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic GISTs, imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can be used.

  • PDGF receptor A

  • Peaks at 60 years of age.
  • M/C symptom: Upper GI bleeding
  • Other symptoms: Pain, lump, perforation, incidental finding
  • Carney's Triad: Sporadic GIST, Paraganglioma, Pulmonary chondroma

Management:

  • IOC for primary GIST: CECT abdomen
  • IOC for recurrent GIST: PET-CT
  • IHC markers: CD117/C-KIT (M/C), DOG 1 (most specific), CD 34

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal pain, which is worse during menstruation. Laparoscopic examination of the pelvis demonstrates multiple small brown spots on the surface of pelvic structures and extensive fibrous adhesions between tubes, ovaries, and other structures. A biopsy is done and microscopy is as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Microscopy shows glands resembling endometrial glands surrounded by endometrial stroma in the ovary. The most likely diagnosis is endometriosis. 

Endometriosis is defined by the presence of ectopic endometrial tissue at a site outside of the uterus. Includes both endometrial glands and stroma, but may consist only of stroma in some cases. 

It occurs in the following sites, in descending order of frequency

  • Ovaries
  • Uterine ligaments
  • Rectovaginal septum
  • Cul de sac
  • Pelvic peritoneum
  • Large and small bowel and appendix
  • Mucosa of the cervix, vagina, and fallopian tubes
  • Laparotomy scars.

It is principally a disease of women in active reproductive life, most often in the third and fourth decades. It causes infertility, dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation), pelvic pain, and other problems. Endometriotic lesions bleed periodically in response to both extrinsic cyclic (ovarian) and intrinsic hormonal stimulation.

The diagnosis is readily made when both endometrial glands and stroma are present with or without the presence of hemosiderin. In rare cases, only the stroma is identified.

Atypical endometriosis, the likely precursor to endometriosis-related ovarian carcinoma, has two morphologic appearances. One consists of cytologic atypia of the epithelium lining the endometriotic cyst without major architectural changes. The second is marked by glandular crowding due to excessive epithelial proliferation, often associated with cytologic atypia, producing an appearance that resembles complex atypical endometrial hyperplasia.

Other options

Option A- Adenomyosis is characterized by foci of the endometrium deep in the myometrium.

Option B- Chronic endometritis is a chronic inflammation of the endometrium.

Option C- Metastatic endometrial carcinoma would be characterized by abnormal glands and cytologic atypia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with chronic bacterial prostatitis was treated with cotrimoxazole.  Within a few days, he developed malaise, jaundice, abdominal pain, and dark urine. The blood picture is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for arteriolar wall thickening in hyaline arteriosclerosis?
questions.solution:
The arteriolar wall thickening in hyaline arteriosclerosis occurs as a result of plasma protein deposition.

Hyaline arteriosclerosis occurs due to injury to the endothelial cells. This allows plasma protein leakage into the arteriolar wall. The endothelial injury also stimulates increased matrix synthesis by the smooth muscle cells. These lead to the deposition of homogenous pink hyaline material causing the thickening of arteriolar walls.

questions.text: Histopathological images of the oesophageal biopsies are given below. What of the following adaptive mechanisms is observed in the epithelium?
questions.solution:

The image on the left is Barrett's esophagus with non-dysplasia and on the right is Barrett's esophagus with low-grade dysplasia. The adaptive mechanism that is observed here is metaplasia.

Metaplasia is a reversible transformation where a differentiated cell type, either epithelial or mesenchymal, is replaced by another cell type. It serves as an adaptive reaction, where a cell type susceptible to specific stress is substituted by another cell type that can better endure unfavorable conditions. The most frequent form of epithelial metaplasia is the transition from columnar to squamous cells, which can be observed in the respiratory tract as a response to persistent irritation.

questions.text: The below given appearance is related to:
questions.solution:
In the given image, the black arrow points towards maltese cross, and yellow arrow points towards the ring form seen in Babesia.

Babesia, a genus of protozoan organisms that includes Babesia microti and Babesia duncani, are responsible for babesiosis. Ixodid ticks are the definitive host. Man is an intermediate host. Sporozoites are the infective form of humans.

The mode of infection is through a tick bite. Occasionally it can also be through blood transfusion.

The majority of the clinical symptoms are predominantly caused by hemolysis of the infected erythrocytes. The illness develops 1-6 weeks after the tick bite. It might be a mild, self-limiting, asymptomatic, or severe sickness that resembles malaria.
Malaise, exhaustion, high-grade fever (38°C to 40.6°C) with chills and sweating, myalgia, arthralgia, a dry cough, and anorexia are symptoms of acute illness.

Complications of acute babesiosis include renal failure, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and congestive cardiac failure (CCF).

On microscopic examination by Giemsa stain, Babesia trophozoites appear as intraerythrocytic round or pyriform or ring form. The ring form is the most common and it lacks the central hemozoin deposit which differentiates it from P. falciparum. Other distinguishing features are the absence of schizonts and gametocytes and the presence of tetrads/Maltese crosses, which are pathognomonic of B. microti or B. duncani.

Treatment of B. microti infection

  • Mild infection is treated with atovaquone along with azithromycin
  • Severe infections are treated with azithromycin along with atovaquone or clindamycin along with quinine
  • Exchange transfusion is required in patients with high-grade parasitemia (≥10%), severe anaemia, and pulmonary, hepatic, or renal compromise.

Other Babesia infections are treated with a combination of clindamycin and quinine.

questions.text: A young man presented with hypertensive episodes, bloody stools and cutaneous nodules. He has a past history of hepatitis B infection. Vasculitis was suspected and a biopsy of the vessel was done. The histopathology of the tissue from the vessel is shown below. Identify the type of necrosis.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polyarteritis nodosa and the above image depicts fibrinoid necrosis. It is seen in vasculitis like polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) in which the small and medium-sized blood vessels are affected as a result of immune complex deposition.

Polyarteritis nodosa is a medium and small-sized vessel vasculitis typically affecting the renal and visceral arteries, sparing pulmonary vessels. Patients present with variable symptoms including accelerated hypertension, abdominal pain, gastrointestinal bleeding, myalgias and cutaneous nodules. It is often associated with chronic hepatitis B infection, which causes the HBsAg-HbsAb complexes to deposit in affected vessels. Clinical manifestations are a result of ischemia and infarction of organs and tissues that are affected.

The diagnosis is based on the histopathological findings seen on a biopsy of the involved organs. Diagnosis can also be made by the demonstration of aneurysms of small and medium-sized arteries in the renal, hepatic, and visceral vasculature. 

Fibrinoid necrosis occurs in blood vessels in which the antigen-antibody complexes get deposited in the blood vessel walls. These complexes elicit an immune reaction leading to cell injury and leakage of fibrin and plasma proteins around the blood vessel and giving a circumferential pinkish appearance of necrosis. 

It is treated with immunosuppressive agents and has a high risk of mortality if left untreated.

The image below shows fibrinoid necrosis with intraluminal thrombosis in an artery of a patient with polyarteritis nodosa. 

Necrosis refers to irreversible cell death caused by the denaturation of proteins and enzymatic digestion of the injured cells. 

Gangrenous necrosis commonly occurs in the lower limbs due to decreased blood supply. This type of necrosis is usually coagulative necrosis and is called dry gangrene.

When this becomes superimposed with bacterial infection the harmful enzymes from the bacteria and inflammatory cells result in liquefactive necrosis which is called wet gangrene.

Caseous necrosis (cheese like) refers to a friable yellow white area of necrosis as seen in this image

  • On microscopic examination, the necrotic focus appears as a collection of fragmented or lysed cells with an amorphous granular pink appearance surrounded by inflammatory cells called as granuloma and is classical of tuberculosis as shown below.

Fat necrosis refers to the localised destruction of fat by pancreatic enzymes. The commonest cause of this type of necrosis is acute pancreatitis. In acute pancreatitis, these enzymes are released within or around the pancreas breaking down the triglycerides into fatty acids. When calcium binds to fatty acid it results in fat saponification giving a chalky white appearance.

Polyarteritis nodosa is a medium and small-sized vessel vasculitis typically affecting the renal and visceral arteries. Patients present with variable symptoms including accelerated hypertension, abdominal pain, gastrointestinal bleeding, myalgias and cutaneous nodules. It is often associated with chronic hepatitis B infection. Histology shows characteristic fibrinoid necrosis of the vessel wall with intraluminal thrombosis. This condition is treated with immunosuppressive agents and has a high risk of mortality.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man was referred with severe anemia and hepatosplenomegaly. Peripheral smear showed teardrop cells, nucleated RBCs, and giant abnormal platelets. Bone marrow aspirate could not be obtained despite multiple attempts, hence a bone marrow biopsy was done. The findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows the deposition of numerous collagen fibers in the bone marrow, which indicates marrow fibrosis. These clinical findings and history of a dry tap on bone marrow aspiration are diagnostic of primary myelofibrosis.

In this condition, the neoplastic proliferation of hematopoietic stem cells results in increased and abnormal proliferation of the megakaryocytes. These megakaryocytes release excessive amounts of platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and TGF-β. Increased growth factors lead to the deposition of collagen in the bone marrow which eventually leads to fibrosis. 

The clinical features include:

  • Early phase:
    • Thrombocytosis (large, abnormal platelets) and leukocytosis
    • Hypercellularity of bone marrow
  • Late phase:
    • Pancytopenia 
    • Hypocellularity and fibrosis of bone marrow (dry tap)
    • Teardrop-shaped RBCs and leukoerythroblastosis (premature release of nucleated erythroid and early granulocytes into blood)
  • Hepatosplenomegaly - due to extramedullary hematopoiesis.

The FDA approved fedratinib, a JAK2-selective inhibitor for the treatment of adult patients with intermediate or high-risk primary or secondary myelofibrosis.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with fever, pain, and swelling in the left mid-thigh region. X-ray shows lamellated periosteal reaction resembling an onion skin. A biopsy from the lesion is shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Ewing's sarcoma.

It is a malignant bone tumor that occurs primarily in children and young adults, in the age group of 10-20 years. It usually affects the long bones, such as the femur, tibia, or humerus. Occasionally, the tumor may begin in the muscles or soft tissues (extraosseous Ewing's sarcoma).

Microscopically, solid sheets of small uniform round cells with PAS-positive magenta pink colored cytoplasm are characteristic of Ewing’s Sarcoma/PNET. The cells show PAS positivity due to the presence of large amounts of cytoplasmic glycogen. This is an important feature for the differential diagnosis of Ewing's with other small round cell tumors.
